repnme.cdata!:
Costa Rica - Third Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Structural Adjustment Loan for
            Costa Rica was terminated on March 1, 1995 since some
            conditions of effectiveness had not yet been met. Soon after
            the loan was signed in April 1993, the project became
            enmeshed in the June 1993 to February 1994 presidential
            campaign. The project required ambitious reforms in
            restructuring the public sector and drew opposition. The new
            Government administration which took office in May 1994
            confirmed its commitment to the broad objectives of the
            loan, but disagreed with some specific conditions.
            Meanwhile, general economic conditions deteriorated sharply
            in 1994. The Bank granted five extensions to the
            effectiveness conditions. However, Bank decided that the
            poor macroeconomic framework and the failure of the
            Government to pass several critical pieces of legislation
            forced the cancellation of the project. Perhaps the most
            important lesson learned concerns the importance of
            ownership of a reform program. This project was eventually
            terminated because the program had been designed,
            negotiated, and signed by one administration, but had to be
            implemented by a new administration with a markedly
            different approach. A second lesson relates to the nature of
            conditionality, particularly enactment of laws. If certain
            laws are absolutely necessary, they are best required as
            conditions for negotiations or for Board presentation even
            if this would lead to delays.

6856273.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Economic management,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Costa Rica - Third Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Structural Adjustment Loan
            Project (SAL) will support the government's structural
            adjustment program, which is designed to: (a) reform the
            public sector to improve its efficiency and strengthen
            fiscal policies; (b) improve incentives for greater export
            orientation and private sector activity; (c) strengthen
            competitiveness of private financial institutions and
            prudential supervision of the financial system; and (d)
            increase coverage and efficiency of social programs, and
            reform the pension system. The SAL will support the
            following set of reforms: (1) maintenance of a macroeconomic
            framework to ensure continued stability; (w) public sector
            reform to: (i) privatize government services and
            enterprises, (ii) reduce public sector employment, (iii)
            improve the budget process, and (iv) rationalize and expand
            the tax base; (3) trade reforms to: (i) reduce the level of
            protection, (ii) remove price and profit margin contols,
            (iii) strengthen regulatory framework for public utilities,
            and (iv) improve export incentives; (4) financial sector
            reforms to: (i) reduce discrimination against private
            financial institutions, (ii) limit subsidized credit, (iii)
            strengthen prudential supervision, and (iv) demonopolize the
            insurance sector; and (5) social sector reforms to: (i)
            improve targeting and coverage of social programs, (ii)
            strengthen programs to retrain displaced public sector
            employees; and (iii) reform the pension system to improve
            equity and solvency.
